pr_title: Simplify VisibilityScriptingBugTest and add test retries to TestNG tests

timeline.message:
Revert "Update vanilla institution to support the new test"

This reverts commit 808ed8a9cc1c11df05065416523334bce18c3e5a.
Only modify the necessary files within vanilla institution to work the test

Simplify the test

Only use one control for testing - the name control.

Add new RetryAnalyzer and TestAnnotationTransformer

Includes logging of retry information. (max number of retries,
current retry, stacktrace of the failure that caused the retry)
Set default vanilla institution UI mode to false

timeline.bodyText:
How about a default of 3?
Seems odd to have 0 for a Max.
Or should we have a DefaultRetry annotation that stacks on this and has the value as zero?
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.author: SammyIsConfused

timeline.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText: Is this required? If so, does that mean this is instantiated as a singleton? If so, does that mean we have concurrency issues with this?
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: I don't think it's required. Each individual test that requires one instantiates a FailureRetryAnalyzer of its own.
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

replies.bodyText: Phew, in that case might as well drop it.
replies.author: edalex-ian

timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText:
Your suggestion will not work.
LOGGER.warning() helper function doesn't have a stack trace method like LOGGER.error does. In order to get a stack trace, and a warning label, you must LOGGER.log(level, message, throwable)
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

replies.bodyText: The purpose here was so that when a TestNG method fails and retries, the initial failure will still log a stack trace.
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

replies.bodyText:
Your suggestion will not work.

Yup, as it appears we're not using log4j, just vanilla JRE logging. We should be using log4j

The purpose here was so that when a TestNG method fails and retries, the initial failure will still log a stack trace.

But what does that offer when we already have the report that test t from class c is retrying? We don't want our logs for testing even more verbose unless it serves a purpose.
replies.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: The idea I had for that is that if some test is flakey, we can look into why it was breaking without letting it fail the whole run. But if you don't think that's worthwhile I'm happy to remove it.
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

replies.bodyText:
Okay, so as discussed just now, this is to capture initial details of a test that eventually passes but we may want to go back at a later date an look into the flakiness.
Seeing this would really be the exception to the norm, let's log the stacktrace at 'debug' once the logger is changed over to log4j.
replies.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText: This message is kind of redundant isn't it?
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: This was just for logging purposes - without this it would go straight to the stack trace, and that could potentially look too similar to a standard failed test.
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

replies.bodyText: Gotcha. Well, let's remove this and the stack trace.
replies.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText:
Does this get called before the first test run, of before the first retry?
(As we don't want any log message for a single successful run.)
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: this gets called after a run that has @MaxRetryCount annotation fails, before it retries.
replies.author: SammyIsConfused

timeline.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText: Do we have the log4j framework overhere? (Or Slf4j?)
timeline.author: edalex-ian

timeline.message: Add back items and acls related to DRMPrivilegeTest
Use slf4j rather than standard logger

Rename MaxRetryCount.java annotation to RetryTest.java

Makes more sense when used - add @RetryTest to a test
method for a default 3 retries.

Handle RetryTest(0) as an annotation

Simply gets ignored.

Add back resources in vanilla institution required for other tests

Namely FavouriteItemsTest, PortalTest and TokenLoginTest.
